blocks.name: inf0
blocks.content: Our Axiom of Infinity derived from existence of omega. The proof shows that the especially contrived class " ` ran ( rec ( ( v e. _V |-> suc v ) , x ) |`` _om ) ` " exists, is a subset of its union, and contains a given set ` x ` (and thus is nonempty). Thus, it provides an example demonstrating that a set ` y ` exists with the necessary properties demanded by ~ ax-inf . (Contributed by NM, 15-Oct-1996.)

  -| diffss(s0, s2)
  -| diffss(s1, s2)

  elrab2(hs0, c0, cfv(c1, c2), cv(s0), wss(cin(c0, cv(s0)), c2), wss(cin(cv(hs0), cv(s0)), c2))

thm inf3lemb(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3) {
  |- wceq(cfv(c0, emptycls), emptycls)
  -| wceq(c1, cmpt(s0, universe, crab(s1, cv(s2), wss(cin(cv(s1), cv(s2)), cv(s0)))))
  -| wceq(c0, cres(crdg(c1, emptycls), com))
  -| wcel(c2, universe)
  -| wcel(c3, universe)
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffss(s0, s2)
  -| diffss(s1, s2)
} = {
  a1ii(wceq(cfv(c0, emptycls), emptycls), wceq(c1, cmpt(s0, universe, crab(s1, cv(s2), wss(cin(cv(s1), cv(s2)), cv(s0))))))
  a1ii(wceq(cfv(c0, emptycls), emptycls), wcel(c2, universe))
  a1ii(wceq(cfv(c0, emptycls), emptycls), wcel(c3, universe))
  a1ii(wceq(cfv(c0, emptycls), emptycls), diffss(s0, s1))
  a1ii(wceq(cfv(c0, emptycls), emptycls), diffss(s0, s2))
  a1ii(wceq(cfv(c0, emptycls), emptycls), diffss(s1, s2))
  eqtri(cfv(c0, emptycls), emptycls, cfv(cres(crdg(c1, emptycls), com), emptycls))
  fveq1i(c0, emptycls, cres(crdg(c1, emptycls), com))
  ax-mp(wceq(cfv(cres(crdg(c1, emptycls), com), emptycls), emptycls), wcel(emptycls, universe))
  0ex()
  fr0g(emptycls, universe, c1)
}

  syl5ibr(wcel(cv(hs1), com), wss(cfv(c1, cv(hs1)), cfv(c1, csuc(cv(hs1)))), wi(wcel(cv(hs0), cfv(c1, csuc(cv(hs1)))), wcel(cv(hs0), cfv(c1, csuc(csuc(cv(hs1)))))), wi(wa(wcel(cv(hs0), cv(s2)), wss(cin(cv(hs0), cv(s2)), cfv(c1, cv(hs1)))), wa(wcel(cv(hs0), cv(s2)), wss(cin(cv(hs0), cv(s2)), cfv(c1, csuc(cv(hs1)))))))

  sstr2(cin(cv(hs0), cv(s2)), cfv(c1, cv(hs1)), cfv(c1, csuc(cv(hs1))))
  imbi12d(wcel(cv(hs1), com), wcel(cv(hs0), cfv(c1, csuc(cv(hs1)))), wcel(cv(hs0), cfv(c1, csuc(csuc(cv(hs1))))), wa(wcel(cv(hs0), cv(s2)), wss(cin(cv(hs0), cv(s2)), cfv(c1, cv(hs1)))), wa(wcel(cv(hs0), cv(s2)), wss(cin(cv(hs0), cv(s2)), cfv(c1, csuc(cv(hs1))))))

thm inf3lem1(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3) {
  ⊢ (c0 ∈ _om →(c1 ` c0)⊆(c1 ` suc(c0)))
  ⊣ c2 =(s0 ∈ 𝕌 ↦ { s1 ∈ s2 |(s1 ⋂ s2)⊆ s0 })
  ⊣ c1 =(rec(c2, ∅)|` _om)
  ⊣ c0 ∈ 𝕌
  ⊣ c3 ∈ 𝕌
  ⊣ d(s0, s1)
  ⊣ d(s0, s2)
  ⊣ d(s1, s2)
} = {
  a1ii((c0 ∈ _om →(c1 ` c0)⊆(c1 ` suc(c0))), c3 ∈ 𝕌)
  finds(hs0, hs1, c0, (c1 ` c0)⊆(c1 ` suc(c0)), (c1 ` hs0)⊆(c1 ` suc(hs0)), (c1 ` ∅)⊆(c1 ` suc(∅)), (c1 ` hs1)⊆(c1 ` suc(hs1)), (c1 ` suc(hs1))⊆(c1 ` suc(suc(hs1))))
  sseq12d((c1 ` hs0), (c1 ` suc(hs0)), (c1 ` ∅), (c1 ` suc(∅)), hs0 = ∅)
  fveq2(hs0, emptycls, c1)
  fveq2d(c1, suc(hs0), suc(∅), hs0 = ∅)
  suceq(hs0, emptycls)
  sseq12d((c1 ` hs0), (c1 ` suc(hs0)), (c1 ` hs1), (c1 ` suc(hs1)), hs0 = hs1)
  fveq2(hs0, hs1, c1)
  fveq2d(c1, suc(hs0), suc(hs1), hs0 = hs1)
  suceq(hs0, hs1)
  sseq12d((c1 ` hs0), (c1 ` suc(hs0)), (c1 ` suc(hs1)), (c1 ` suc(suc(hs1))), hs0 = suc(hs1))
  fveq2(hs0, suc(hs1), c1)
  fveq2d(c1, suc(hs0), suc(suc(hs1)), hs0 = suc(hs1))
  suceq(hs0, suc(hs1))
  sseq12d((c1 ` hs0), (c1 ` suc(hs0)), (c1 ` c0), (c1 ` suc(c0)), hs0 = c0)
  fveq2(hs0, c0, c1)
  fveq2d(c1, suc(hs0), suc(c0), hs0 = c0)
  suceq(hs0, c0)
  eqsstri((c1 ` ∅), (c1 ` suc(∅)), emptycls)
  inf3lemb(s0, s1, s2, c1, c2, c0, c0)
  0ss((c1 ` suc(∅)))
  ex(hs1 ∈ _om, (c1 ` hs1)⊆(c1 ` suc(hs1)), (c1 ` suc(hs1))⊆(c1 ` suc(suc(hs1))))
  ssrdv(hs0, (c1 ` suc(hs1)), (c1 ` suc(suc(hs1))), (hs1 ∈ _om ∧(c1 ` hs1)⊆(c1 ` suc(hs1))))
  imp(hs1 ∈ _om, (c1 ` hs1)⊆(c1 ` suc(hs1)), (hs0 ∈(c1 ` suc(hs1))→ hs0 ∈(c1 ` suc(suc(hs1)))))
  syl5ibr(hs1 ∈ _om, (c1 ` hs1)⊆(c1 ` suc(hs1)), (hs0 ∈(c1 ` suc(hs1))→ hs0 ∈(c1 ` suc(suc(hs1)))), ((hs0 ∈ s2 ∧(hs0 ⋂ s2)⊆(c1 ` hs1))→(hs0 ∈ s2 ∧(hs0 ⋂ s2)⊆(c1 ` suc(hs1)))))
  anim2d((c1 ` hs1)⊆(c1 ` suc(hs1)), hs0 ∈ s2, (hs0 ⋂ s2)⊆(c1 ` hs1), (hs0 ⋂ s2)⊆(c1 ` suc(hs1)))
  com12((c1 ` hs1)⊆(c1 ` suc(hs1)), (hs0 ⋂ s2)⊆(c1 ` hs1), (hs0 ⋂ s2)⊆(c1 ` suc(hs1)))
  sstr2((hs0 ⋂ s2), (c1 ` hs1), (c1 ` suc(hs1)))
  imbi12d(hs1 ∈ _om, hs0 ∈(c1 ` suc(hs1)), hs0 ∈(c1 ` suc(suc(hs1))), (hs0 ∈ s2 ∧(hs0 ⋂ s2)⊆(c1 ` hs1)), (hs0 ∈ s2 ∧(hs0 ⋂ s2)⊆(c1 ` suc(hs1))))
  syl6bb(hs1 ∈ _om, hs0 ∈(c1 ` suc(hs1)), (hs0 ∈ s2 ∧(hs0 ⋂ s2)⊆(c1 ` hs1)), hs0 ∈(c2 `(c1 ` hs1)))
  eleq2d(hs0, (c1 ` suc(hs1)), (c2 `(c1 ` hs1)), hs1 ∈ _om)
  inf3lemc(s0, s1, s2, hs1, c1, c2, c0)
  inf3lema(s2, s0, s1, hs0, c2, (c1 ` hs1), c1)
  fvex(c1, hs1)
  syl6bb(hs1 ∈ _om, hs0 ∈(c1 ` suc(suc(hs1))), (hs0 ∈ s2 ∧(hs0 ⋂ s2)⊆(c1 ` suc(hs1))), hs0 ∈(c2 `(c1 ` suc(hs1))))
  eleq2d(hs0, (c1 ` suc(suc(hs1))), (c2 `(c1 ` suc(hs1))), hs1 ∈ _om)
  sylbi(hs1 ∈ _om, (c1 ` suc(suc(hs1)))=(c2 `(c1 ` suc(hs1))), suc(hs1)∈ _om)
  peano2b(hs1)
  inf3lemc(s0, s1, s2, suc(hs1), c1, c2, c0)
  sucex(hs1)
  vex(hs1)
  inf3lema(s2, s0, s1, hs0, c2, (c1 ` suc(hs1)), c1)
  vex(hs0)
  fvex(c1, suc(hs1))
  diff.hs0.s(hs1)
  diff.hs0.c(c0)
  diff.hs0.w((c1 ` c0)⊆(c1 ` suc(c0)))
  diff.hs0.w((c1 ` ∅)⊆(c1 ` suc(∅)))
  diff.hs0.w((c1 ` hs1)⊆(c1 ` suc(hs1)))
  diff.hs0.w((c1 ` suc(hs1))⊆(c1 ` suc(suc(hs1))))
  diff.hs1.w((c1 ` hs0)⊆(c1 ` suc(hs0)))
  diff.hs0.c((c1 ` suc(hs1)))
  diff.hs0.c((c1 ` suc(suc(hs1))))
  diff.hs0.w((hs1 ∈ _om ∧(c1 ` hs1)⊆(c1 ` suc(hs1))))
  diffss.ex(s2, s0)
  diffss.ex(s2, s1)
}

blocks.content: Lemma for our Axiom of Infinity => standard Axiom of Infinity. See ~ inf3 for detailed description. (Contributed by NM, 28-Oct-1996.)

blocks.name: inf3
blocks.content:
Our Axiom of Infinity ~ ax-inf implies the standard Axiom of Infinity. The hypothesis is a variant of our Axiom of Infinity provided by ~ inf2 , and the conclusion is the version of the Axiom of Infinity shown as Axiom 7 in [TakeutiZaring] p. 43. (Other standard versions are proved later as ~ axinf2 and ~ zfinf2 .) The main proof is provided by ~ inf3lema through ~ inf3lem7 , and this final piece eliminates the auxiliary hypothesis of ~ inf3lem7 . This proof is due to Ian Sutherland, Richard Heck, and Norman Megill and was posted on Usenet as shown below. Although the result is not new, the authors were unable to find a published proof. 
 (As posted to sci.logic on 30-Oct-1996, with annotations added.) Theorem: The statement "There exists a nonempty set that is a subset of its union" implies the Axiom of Infinity. Proof: Let X be a nonempty set which is a subset of its union; the latter property is equivalent to saying that for any y in X, there exists a z in X such that y is in z. Define by finite recursion a function F:omega-->(power X) such that F_0 = 0 (See ~ inf3lemb .) F_n+1 = {y<X | y^X subset F_n} (See ~ inf3lemc .) Note: ^ means intersect, < means \in ("element of"). (Finite recursion as typically done requires the existence of omega; to avoid this we can just use transfinite recursion restricted to omega. F is a class-term that is not necessarily a set at this point.) Lemma 1. F_n subset F_n+1. (See ~ inf3lem1 .) Proof: By induction: F_0 subset F_1. If y < F_n+1, then y^X subset F_n, so if F_n subset F_n+1, then y^X subset F_n+1, so y < F_n+2. Lemma 2. F_n =/= X. (See ~ inf3lem2 .) Proof: By induction: F_0 =/= X because X is not empty. Assume F_n =/= X. Then there is a y in X that is not in F_n. By definition of X, there is a z in X that contains y. Suppose F_n+1 = X. Then z is in F_n+1, and z^X contains y, so z^X is not a subset of F_n, contrary to the definition of F_n+1. Lemma 3. F_n =/= F_n+1. (See ~ inf3lem3 .) Proof: Using the identity y^X subset F_n <-> y^(X-F_n) = 0, we have F_n+1 = {y<X | y^(X-F_n) = 0}. Let q = {y<X-F_n | y^(X-F_n) = 0}. Then q subset F_n+1. Since X-F_n is not empty by Lemma 2 and q is the set of \in-minimal elements of X-F_n, by Foundation q is not empty, so q and therefore F_n+1 have an element not in F_n. Lemma 4. F_n proper_subset F_n+1. (See ~ inf3lem4 .) Proof: Lemmas 1 and 3. Lemma 5. F_m proper_subset F_n, m < n. (See ~ inf3lem5 .) Proof: Fix m and use induction on n > m. Basis: F_m proper_subset F_m+1 by Lemma 4. Induction: Assume F_m proper_subset F_n. Then since F_n proper_subset F_n+1, F_m proper_subset F_n+1 by transitivity of proper subset. By Lemma 5, F_m =/= F_n for m =/= n, so F is 1-1. (See ~ inf3lem6 .) Thus, the inverse of F is a function with range omega and domain a subset of power X, so omega exists by Replacement. (See ~ inf3lem7 .) Q.E.D.
(Contributed by NM, 29-Oct-1996.)

blocks.name: infeq5
blocks.content: The statement "there exists a set that is a proper subset of its union" is equivalent to the Axiom of Infinity (shown on the right-hand side in the form of ~ omex .) The left-hand side provides us with a very short way to express the Axiom of Infinity using only elementary symbols. This proof of equivalence does not depend on the Axiom of Infinity. (Contributed by NM, 23-Mar-2004.) (Revised by Mario Carneiro, 16-Nov-2014.)
